{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia frigida |accepted_authority=Willdenow |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=3: 1838. 1803 |year=1803 }} |common_names=Fringed sage;prairie sagewort;armoise douce |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia frigida var. gmeliniana |authority=(Besser) Besser |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia frigida var. williamsiae |authority=S. L. Welsh |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Absinthium;Artemisia frigida |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Absinthium]]
species[[Artemisia frigida]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 519 }}Perennials, 10–40 cm (forming silvery mats or mounds), strongly aromatic. Stems gray-green or brown, glabrescent. Leaves persistent, silver-gray; blades ovate, 0.5–1.5(–2.5) cm, 1–2-ternately lobed (lobes 0.2–0.5 mm wide), faces densely whitish-pubescent. Heads in (leafy) paniculiform arrays 0.5–2(–4) × 4–15(–20) cm. Involucres globose, (3–)5 × (2–)5–6 mm. Phyllaries gray-green (margins sometimes brownish), densely tomentose. Florets: pistillate 10–17; bisexual 20–50; corollas 1.5–2 mm, glabrous. Cypselae 1–1.5 mm, glabrous. 2n = 18.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer–fall. |habitat=Fields, meadows, dry grasslands, steppes, usually stony, well-drained soils |elevation=500–3300 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;N.W.T.;Nunavut;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Yukon;Alaska;Ariz.;Colo.;Idaho;Ill.;Iowa;Kans.;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;N.Mex.;N.Dak.;S.Dak.;Tex.;Utah;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo.;Eurasia. |discussion=

Reports of Artemisia frigida from eastern Canada (Ontario eastward), the eastern United States (e.g., Connecticut, Massachusetts, Michigan, Vermont), and Arkansas and Missouri appear to be from old garden sites where the plants may persist. The similarity of this native species to cultivars from eastern Asia (especially Siberia) has led to a number of reports that are apparently based on other cultivars. As a plant with attractive silver foliage, this species has good potential as a drought-hardy plant for flower gardens in cold climates.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia frigida |authority=Willdenow |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms=Artemisia frigida var. gmeliniana;Artemisia frigida var. williamsiae |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer–fall. |habitat=Fields, meadows, dry grasslands, steppes, usually stony, well-drained soils |elevation=500–3300 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;N.W.T.;Nunavut;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Yukon;Alaska;Ariz.;Colo.;Idaho;Ill.;Iowa;Kans.;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;N.Mex.;N.Dak.;S.Dak.;Tex.;Utah;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo.;Eurasia. |reference=None |publication title=Sp. Pl. |publication year=1803 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_886.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Absinthium |species=Artemisia frigida }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Absinthium]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia furcata |accepted_authority=M. Bieberstein |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. Taur.-Caucas. |place=3: 567. 1819 |year=1819 }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia furcata var. heterophylla |authority=(Besser) Hultén |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia hyperborea |authority=Rydberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia tacomensis |authority=Stephani ex Sprengel |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia trifurcata |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia furcata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia furcata]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 521, 526 |treatment_page=page 525 }}Perennials, 7–35 cm (not cespitose), faintly aromatic (not rhizomatous, taproots stout, caudices simple or branched, branches clothed with persistent leaf bases). Stems (flowering) 1–5, erect, light brown, simple, strigillose or glabrate. Leaves basal (in rosettes) and cauline, gray-green; blades oval, 2–10(–12) cm (basal) or 1–1.5 × 0.4–0.6 cm (cauline), 1–3-palmately lobed, faces sparsely to densely strigillose. Heads (erect or spreading, some nodding, peduncles 0 or to 30 mm) in racemiform or spiciform arrays 1–6 × 1–2 cm. Involucres broadly campanulate, 3–6 × 4.5–8 mm. Phyllaries (greenish, color often obscured by indument) ovate or lanceolate (margins dark brown), sparsely to densely tomentose. Florets: pistillate 6–7; bisexual 15–26; corollas mostly yellow, sometimes red-tinged, 1–2 mm, glabrous or glabrate. Cypselae oblong (ribbed), 1–1.5 mm, glabrous. 2n = 18, 36, 72, 90.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer. |habitat=Talus slopes or tundra |elevation=500–2700 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;N.W.T.;Nunavut;Yukon;Alaska;Wash.;Asia. |discussion=

Artemisia furcata extends from the islands of the Bering Sea into southern and interior Alaska, parts of Canada (disjunct in British Columbia and the northernmost Rocky Mountains of Alberta), and on Mt. Rainier in Washington. The array of names applied to A. furcata shows the taxonomic confusion arising from a myriad of morphologic variants that may indicate introgression with other species.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia furcata |authority=M. Bieberstein |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms=Artemisia furcata var. heterophylla;Artemisia hyperborea;Artemisia tacomensis;Artemisia trifurcata |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering late summer. |habitat=Talus slopes or tundra |elevation=500–2700 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;N.W.T.;Nunavut;Yukon;Alaska;Wash.;Asia. |reference=None |publication title=Fl. Taur.-Caucas. |publication year=1819 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_899.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia furcata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia globularia |accepted_authority=Chamisso ex Besser |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Nouv. Mém. Soc. Imp. Naturalistes Moscou |place=3: 64. 1833 |year=1833 }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ajania globularia |authority=(Besser) Poljakov |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia norvegica subsp. globularia |authority=(Besser) H. M. Hall & Clements |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia globularia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia globularia]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 521 |treatment_page=page 525 }}Perennials, (3–)5–16(–30) cm (cespitose), faintly aromatic (not rhizomatous, taproots stout, caudices simple or branched, proximal branches clothed with persistent leaf bases). Stems 1–5, erect, whitish gray, densely tomentose. Leaves mostly basal (cauline 1–4), greenish to whitish green; blades (basal) 1–4.5 × 0.6–1.5 cm, 1–2-ternately to palmately lobed (flowering-stem blades 3-lobed), faces sparsely hairy. Heads (2–20, peduncles 0 or to 25 mm) in subcapitate to capitate arrays 2–3 × 2–3 cm. Involucres campanulate or hemispheric, 3.5–6 × 6–11 mm. Phyllaries lanceolate (margins brown), pilose. Florets: pistillate 9–10; bisexual 20–30; corollas yellow or reddish black, 2–3 mm, sometimes glandular. Cypselae oblong, 1.5–2.5 mm, (apices flattened) glabrous.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;Asia. |discussion=

Subspecies 2 (2 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Corollas reddish black; cypselae ca. 2.5 mm, margins with relatively narrow ribs |[[Artemisia globularia subsp. globularia|Artemisia globularia subsp. globularia]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Corollas yellow; cypselae 1.5–2 mm, margins with relatively broad ribs |[[Artemisia globularia subsp. lutea|Artemisia globularia subsp. lutea]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia globularia |authority=Chamisso ex Besser |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms=Ajania globularia;Artemisia norvegica subsp. globularia |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;Asia. |reference=None |publication title=Nouv. Mém. Soc. Imp. Naturalistes Moscou |publication year=1833 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_900.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia globularia }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Artemisia subg. Artemisia]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia globularia subsp. globularia |accepted_authority= |publications= |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia globularia;Artemisia globularia subsp. globularia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia globularia]]
subspecies[[Artemisia globularia subsp. globularia]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 525 }}Flowering stems 2–12(–16) cm. Corollas reddish black, eglandular. Cypselae ca. 2.5 mm, margins with relatively narrow ribs. 2n = 18, 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra, interior mountains |elevation=200–1300 m |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;e Asia (Russian Far East). |discussion=

The red color of the glabrous corollas and the larger heads of subsp. globularia distinguish it from the morphologically similar Artemisia glomerata.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia globularia subsp. globularia |authority= |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering late summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra, interior mountains |elevation=200–1300 m |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;e Asia (Russian Far East). |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_901.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia globularia |subspecies=Artemisia globularia subsp. globularia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia globularia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia globularia subsp. lutea |accepted_authority=(Hultén) L. M. Shultz |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sida |place=21: 1638. 2005 |year=2005 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Artemisia globularia var. lutea |authority=Hultén |rank=variety |publication_title=Fl. Alaska Yukon |publication_place=10: 1567. 1950 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia flava |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia globularia;Artemisia globularia subsp. lutea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia globularia]]
subspecies[[Artemisia globularia subsp. lutea]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 525 |treatment_page=page 526 }}Flowering stems 5–9 cm. Corollas yellow, orange-glandular. Cypselae 1.5–2 mm, margins with relatively broad ribs.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Rocky ridges and slopes |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Alaska. |discussion=

Subspecies lutea is common on St. Mathew Island and infrequent on surrounding islands and the mainland (Seward Peninsula). It might be confused with Artemisia furcata.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia globularia subsp. lutea |authority=(Hultén) L. M. Shultz |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Artemisia flava |basionyms=Artemisia globularia var. lutea |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Rocky ridges and slopes |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Alaska. |reference=None |publication title=Sida |publication year=2005 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_902.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia globularia |subspecies=Artemisia globularia subsp. lutea }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia globularia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia glomerata |accepted_authority=Ledebour |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mém. Acad. Imp. Sci. St. Pétersbourg Hist. Acad. |place=5: 564. 1815 |year=1815 }} |common_names=Congested sagewort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ajania glomerata |authority=(Ledebour) Poljakov |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia glomerata var. subglabra |authority=Hultén |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia norvegica var. glomerata |authority=(Ledebour) H. M. Hall & Clements |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia glomerata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia glomerata]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 521, 525 |treatment_page=page 526 }}Perennials, 30–50(–100) cm (densely cespitose), mildly aromatic (not rhizomatous, caudices subterranean, branches clothed with persistent leaf bases). Stems relatively numerous, ascending, brown, simple, hairy. Leaves mostly basal (cauline mostly 2–4, smaller), whitish; blades (basal) flabellate, 0.5–1(–2) × 0.5–0.8(–1.5) cm, relatively deeply lobed (lobes 5–9, linear), faces strigillose. Heads (3–10, erect or nodding, peduncles 0 or to 15 mm) in subcapitate to corymbiform arrays 1–5 × 2–4 cm. Involucres broadly campanulate, 3–4 × 3.5–5 mm. Phyllaries lanceolate (margins brownish), densely pilose. Florets: pistillate 4–5; bisexual 10–15; corollas yellow (3–5-toothed), 2–2.5 mm, glabrous or sparsely pilose. Cypselae ellipsoid (flattened, margins ribbed), 1–1.5 mm, glabrous. 2n = 18, 27, 36, 54.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra and sandy slopes |elevation=0–1000 m |distribution=Yukon;Alaska. |discussion=

Artemisia glomerata is similar to A. senjavinensis; it can be distinguished by its more deeply lobed leaves and sparser indument.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia glomerata |authority=Ledebour |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms=Ajania glomerata;Artemisia glomerata var. subglabra;Artemisia norvegica var. glomerata |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra and sandy slopes |elevation=0–1000 m |distribution=Yukon;Alaska. |reference=None |publication title=Mém. Acad. Imp. Sci. St. Pétersbourg Hist. Acad. |publication year=1815 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_903.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia glomerata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]

revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia laciniata |accepted_authority=Willdenow |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=3: 1843. 1803 |year=1803 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia laciniata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia laciniata]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 521 |treatment_page=page 526 }}Perennials, 5–15 cm (not cespitose), sometimes mildly aromatic. Stems 1–3, erect, reddish brown, simple, strigillose to spreading-hairy, or glabrous. Leaves basal (in rosettes, petioles to 12 cm) and cauline, greenish; blades (basal) 2–3-pinnate, relatively deeply lobed (cauline sessile, 1–2-pinnately lobed to entire), faces sparsely hairy to pilose. Heads (10–70, spreading to nodding, peduncles 0 or to 10 mm) in spiciform arrays 2–5 × 0.5–1 or 8–18 × 1–4 cm. Involucres globose, 3–5 × 4–8 mm. Phyllaries (greenish or yellowish) elliptic (margins hyaline, brownish), glabrous or sparsely hairy. Florets: pistillate 6–8; bisexual 20–50; corollas yellowish or yellow to reddish-tinged, 1–2 mm, hairy (hairs tangled). Cypselae oblong, 0.5–1 mm, glabrous.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;Colo.;Idaho;N.Mex.;Utah;Eurasia. |discussion=

Subspecies 2 (2 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Stems hairy; leaves mostly cauline, blades 5–20 × 1–2 cm, sparsely hairy; arrays of heads 8–18 × 1–4 cm; corollas yellowish, 1–1.5 mm |[[Artemisia laciniata subsp. laciniata|Artemisia laciniata subsp. laciniata]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Stems glabrous; leaves mostly basal, blades of proximalmost 4–8 × 0.5–1 cm, of cauline 1.5–0.8 × 0.2 cm, sericeous; arrays of heads 2–5 × 0.5–1 cm; corollas yellow or reddish-tinged, 1.5–2 mm |[[Artemisia laciniata subsp. parryi|Artemisia laciniata subsp. parryi]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia laciniata |authority=Willdenow |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;Colo.;Idaho;N.Mex.;Utah;Eurasia. |reference=None |publication title=Sp. Pl. |publication year=1803 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_904.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia laciniata }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Artemisia subg. Artemisia]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia laciniata subsp. laciniata |accepted_authority= |publications= |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia laciniatiformis |authority=Komarov |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia macrobotrys |authority=Ledebour |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia laciniata;Artemisia laciniata subsp. laciniata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia laciniata]]
subspecies[[Artemisia laciniata subsp. laciniata]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 526 }}Stems 20–50 cm, hairy. Leaves mostly cauline, blades 5–20 × 1–2 cm, sparsely hairy. Heads in arrays 8–18 × 1–4 cm. Involucres 3–5 × 4–8 mm. Corollas yellowish, 1–1.5 mm. Cypselae 0.5–1 mm. 2n = 18.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Dry, gravelly stream banks, grassy flats, forested areas, dry hillsides |elevation=100–1500 m |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;Eurasia. |discussion=

Widely distributed in Eurasia and often confused with Artemisia norvegica, A. laciniata subsp. laciniata can be distinguished by its well-developed basal leaves and smaller heads.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia laciniata subsp. laciniata |authority= |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Artemisia laciniatiformis;Artemisia macrobotrys |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Dry, gravelly stream banks, grassy flats, forested areas, dry hillsides |elevation=100–1500 m |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;Eurasia. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_905.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia laciniata |subspecies=Artemisia laciniata subsp. laciniata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia laciniata]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia laciniata subsp. parryi |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) W. A. Weber |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=58: 382. 1985 |year=1985 }} |common_names=Parry sagewort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Artemisia parryi |authority=Rydberg |rank=species |publication_title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |publication_place=7: 361. 1868 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia saxicola var. parryi |authority=A. Nelson |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia laciniata;Artemisia laciniata subsp. parryi |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia laciniata]]
subspecies[[Artemisia laciniata subsp. parryi]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 526 |treatment_page=page 527 }}Stems 10–40 cm, glabrous. Leaves mostly basal, faces sericeous; proximalmost 4–8 × 0.5–1 cm, cauline 1.5–0.8 × 0.2 cm. Heads in 2–5 × 0.5–1 cm arrays. Involucres 3–4 × 4–5 mm. Corollas yellow or reddish-tinged, 1.5–2 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer–fall. |habitat=Subalpine and alpine meadows, rocky soils |elevation=2700–3900 m |distribution=Colo.;Idaho;N.Mex.;Utah. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia laciniata subsp. parryi |authority=(A. Gray) W. A. Weber |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Artemisia saxicola var. parryi |basionyms=Artemisia parryi |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering late summer–fall. |habitat=Subalpine and alpine meadows, rocky soils |elevation=2700–3900 m |distribution=Colo.;Idaho;N.Mex.;Utah. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1985 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_906.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia laciniata |subspecies=Artemisia laciniata subsp. parryi }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia laciniata]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia longifolia |accepted_authority=Nuttall |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. N. Amer. Pl. |place=2: 142. 1818 |year=1818 }} |common_names=Long-leaved sage |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia ludoviciana var. integrifolia |authority=A. Nelson |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia natronensis |authority=A. Nelson |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia vulgaris subsp. longifolia |authority=(Nuttall) H. M. Hall & Clements |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia vulgaris var. longifolia |authority=(Nuttall) M. Peck |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia longifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia longifolia]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 521, 532 |treatment_page=page 527 }}Perennials, 20–80 cm (not cespitose), pleasantly aromatic (fibrous-rooted, rootstocks relatively short, horizontal, layered stems sometimes sprouting). Stems 3–20+, erect, gray-green, usually simple, sometimes branched (bases woody), densely tomentose. Leaves cauline, bicolor (white and green); blades linear to lanceolate, 3–12 × 1 cm, margins usually entire, sometimes toothed or lobed, faces densely tomentose (abaxial) or glabrate (adaxial). Heads (peduncles 0 or to 2 mm) in mostly racemiform arrays 8–13 × 1–2 cm. Involucres campanulate, 4–5 × 4–5 mm. Phyllaries ovate-lanceolate (margins hyaline), densely to sparsely tomentose. Florets: pistillate 3–10; bisexual 8–26; corollas pale yellow, 1–2 mm, sparsely glandular. Cypselae ellipsoid, 0.5–0.8 mm, glabrous. 2n = 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–early fall. |habitat=Alkaline flats, grasslands, barren areas, high plains |elevation=500–1800 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;Sask.;Idaho;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;N.Dak.;S.Dak.;Wyo. |discussion=

Artemisia longifolia appears to be more salt-tolerant than most species of the genus. It is closely related to A. ludoviciana.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia longifolia |authority=Nuttall |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms=Artemisia ludoviciana var. integrifolia;Artemisia natronensis;Artemisia vulgaris subsp. longifolia;Artemisia vulgaris var. longifolia |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid summer–early fall. |habitat=Alkaline flats, grasslands, barren areas, high plains |elevation=500–1800 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;Sask.;Idaho;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;N.Dak.;S.Dak.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Gen. N. Amer. Pl. |publication year=1818 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_907.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia longifolia }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Artemisia subg. Artemisia]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia ludoviciana |accepted_authority=Nuttall |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. N. Amer. Pl. |place=2: 143. 1818 |year=1818 }} |common_names=Silver wormwood;white or silver sage |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia vulgaris var. ludoviciana |authority=(Nuttall) Kuntze |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia ludoviciana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia ludoviciana]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 522, 524, 530, 532 |treatment_page=page 527 }}Perennials, 20–80 (rarely to 120 in desert washes) cm, aromatic (rhizomatous). Stems relatively few to relatively numerous, erect, gray-green, simple or widely branched, hairy. Leaves cauline, uniformly gray-green, green, or white, or bicolor (white and green); blades linear to broadly elliptic, 1.5–11 × 0.5–4 cm, entire or lobed to relatively deeply pinnatifid, faces hairy. Heads (erect to nodding, peduncles 0 or 2–5 mm) in congested to open (widely branched) arrays. Involucres campanulate or turbinate, (1–)2–4(–5) × 2–5(–8) mm. Phyllaries (gray-green), lanceolate to ovate or obovate (margins narrowly hyaline), densely tomentose. Florets: pistillate 5–12; bisexual 6–45; corollas yellow, sometimes red-tinged, 1.5–2.8 mm, glabrous. Cypselae ellipsoid ca. 0.5 mm, (obscurely nerved) glabrous. 2n = 18, 36, 54.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ariz.;Ark.;Calif.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;Ga.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Mass.;Md.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;Mont.;N.C.;N.Dak.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;Nebr.;Nev.;Ohio;Okla.;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Utah;Va.;Vt.;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo.;Mexico. |discussion=

Subspecies ca. 7 (6 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Leaves usually relatively deeply lobed (1/3+ widths, nearly to midrib, proximal leaves sometimes entire); involucres 3–8 mm diam.; mountain meadows and slopes |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Leaves entire or relatively shallowly lobed (lobes to 1/3 widths); involucres 2–3(–4) mm diam.; desert valleys and mountains |[[#key-0-3| > 3]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Involucres 4–5 × 4–8 mm |[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. candicans|Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. candicans]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Involucres 3–4 × 3–5 mm |[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. incompta|Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. incompta]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Heads in paniculiform arrays (4–)8–30 cm diam.; leaves mostly 1.5–2 cm |[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. albula|Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. albula]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Heads in paniculiform or racemiform arrays 1–6 cm diam.; leaves 1.5–11 cm |[[#key-0-4| > 4]] |-id=key-0-4 |4 |Leaf margins plane |[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. ludoviciana|Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. ludoviciana]] |-id=key-0-4 |4 |Leaf margins revolute |[[#key-0-5| > 5]] |-id=key-0-5 |5 |Leaves bicolor (gray-green and bright green), margins mostly entire, abaxial faces glabrous |[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. redolens|Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. redolens]] |-id=key-0-5 |5 |Leaves gray-green, margins usually lobed, abaxial faces hairy |[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. mexicana|Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. mexicana]] |}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. albula |accepted_authority=(Wooton) D. D. Keck |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., ser. |place=4, 25: 446. 1946 |year=1946 }} |common_names=White wormwood |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Artemisia albula |authority=Wooton |rank=species |publication_title=Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. |publication_place=16: 193. 1913, }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia ludoviciana;Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. albula |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia ludoviciana]]
subspecies[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. albula]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 527 |treatment_page=page 528 }}Stems 30–80 cm, widely branched, tomentose or glabrous. Leaves uniformly whitish green; blades lance-linear (and entire), or obovate to elliptic (with antrorse teeth or lobes to 1/3 blade lengths, usually 1–2 cm, margins revolute), faces ± tomentose. Heads in open, paniculiform arrays (9–)15–40 × (4–)8–30 cm. Involucres 1–2 × 2–3 mm. Florets: pistillate 8–11; bisexual 8–13; corollas 1–1.5 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early summer–fall. |habitat=Desert drainages, sandy soils |elevation=1500–2000 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. albula |authority=(Wooton) D. D. Keck |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms=Artemisia albula |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering early summer–fall. |habitat=Desert drainages, sandy soils |elevation=1500–2000 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., ser. |publication year=1946 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_910.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia ludoviciana |subspecies=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. albula }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia ludoviciana]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. candicans |accepted_authority=(Rydberg) D. D. Keck |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., ser. |place=4, 25: 447. 1946 |year=1946 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Artemisia candicans |authority=Rydberg |rank=species |publication_title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |publication_place=24: 296. 1897 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia gracilenta |authority=A. Nelson |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia latiloba |authority=(Nuttall) Rydberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia ludoviciana var. candicans |authority=(Rydberg) H. St. John |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia ludoviciana var. latiloba |authority=Nuttall |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia vulgaris subsp. candicans |authority=(Rydberg) H. M. Hall & Clements |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia vulgaris var. candicans |authority=(Rydberg) M. Peck |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia ludoviciana;Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. candicans |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia ludoviciana]]
subspecies[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. candicans]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 527 |treatment_page=page 529 }}Stems 30–50(–80) cm, mostly simple, sparsely tomentose. Leaves ± white; blades broadly obovate to oblong, 4–10 × 1.5–4 cm, relatively deeply lobed (lobes, lanceolate, 1/3+ blade lengths, acute), faces tomentose (usually less densely adaxially). Heads in racemiform arrays 4–7 × 2–4 cm. Involucres (broadly campanulate), 4–5 × 4–8 mm. Florets: pistillate 8–10; bisexual 20–30; corollas 1.5–2 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Mountains, usually in loamy soils |elevation=1800–3000 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Calif.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

Subspecies candicans is broadly circumscribed in this treatment. Variants within the complex, especially var. latiloba, may merit segregation.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. candicans |authority=(Rydberg) D. D. Keck |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Artemisia gracilenta;Artemisia latiloba;Artemisia ludoviciana var. candicans;Artemisia ludoviciana var. latiloba;Artemisia vulgaris subsp. candicans;Artemisia vulgaris var. candicans |basionyms=Artemisia candicans |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Mountains, usually in loamy soils |elevation=1800–3000 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Calif.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., ser. |publication year=1946 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_911.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia ludoviciana |subspecies=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. candicans }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia ludoviciana]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. incompta |accepted_authority=(Nuttall) D. D. Keck |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Publ. Carnegie Inst. Wash. |place=520: 327. 1940 |year=1940 }} |common_names=Mountain wormwood |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Artemisia incompta |authority=Nuttall |rank=species |publication_title=Trans. Amer. Philos. Soc., n. s. |publication_place=7: 400. 1841 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia arachnoidea |authority=E. Sheldon |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia atomifera |authority=Piper |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia lindleyana |authority=Besser |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia ludoviciana var. incompta |authority=(Nuttall) Cronquist |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia prescottiana |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia vulgaris var. incompta |authority=(Nuttall) H. St. John |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia ludoviciana;Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. incompta |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia ludoviciana]]
subspecies[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. incompta]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 527 |treatment_page=page 529 }}Stems 20–50(–80) cm, mostly simple, hairy. Leaves bicolor (white and green, or gray-green and green); blades narrowly to broadly lanceolate, 1.5–11 × 1–1.5 cm, irregularly lobed (lobes usually 1/3+ blade widths), faces hairy (abaxial) or glabrous or glabrescent. Heads in paniculiform arrays (10–)15–25(–35) × (2–)3–8(–10) cm. Involucres (broadly campanulate) 3(–4) × 3(–5) mm. Florets: pistillate 5–12; bisexual 6–45; corollas yellow, sometimes red-tinged, 1.5–2 mm. 2n = 36, 54.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–late fall. |habitat=Open meadows, mountain slopes |elevation=1900–3500 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo.;Mexico. |discussion=

Subspecies incompta varies. It could be (and has been) subdivided. The variation found within one population, as well as from one part of its range to another, makes the recognition of discrete taxa difficult as well as questionable. The morphologic variant treated as Artemisia lindleyana by some authors may warrant infraspecific status.

Nelson) Rydberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia paucicephala |authority=A. Nelson |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia pudica |authority=Rydberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia purshiana |authority=Besser |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia rhizomata |authority=A. Nelson |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia ludoviciana;Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. ludoviciana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia ludoviciana]]
subspecies[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. ludoviciana]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 527 |treatment_page=page 528 }}Stems (gray to white) mostly simple, 30–80 cm, tomentose. Leaves gray; blades linear to narrowly elliptic, 3–11 cm, margins plane (proximalmost entire or apically lobed, lobes to 1/3 blade lengths; cauline 1.5–11 × 1–1.5 cm, entire or lobed to pinnatifid), faces densely tomentose. Heads in congested, paniculiform or racemiform arrays 5–30 × 1–4 cm. Involucres 3–4 × 2–4 mm. Florets: pistillate 5–12; bisexual 6–30; corollas 1.9–2.8 mm. 2n = 18, 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–late fall. |habitat=Disturbed roadsides, open meadows, rocky slopes |elevation=100–3000 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ariz.;Ark.;Calif.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;Ga.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;Mont.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Utah;Vt.;Va.;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo. |discussion=

Subspecies ludoviciana is widespread in North America in diverse habitats. It is the most common subspecies and the most variable morphologically.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. ludoviciana |authority= |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Artemisia brittonii;Artemisia cuneata;Artemisia diversifolia;Artemisia falcata;Artemisia gnaphaloides;Artemisia herriotii;Artemisia lindheimeriana;Artemisia pabularis;Artemisia paucicephala;Artemisia pudica;Artemisia purshiana;Artemisia rhizomata |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid summer–late fall. |habitat=Disturbed roadsides, open meadows, rocky slopes |elevation=100–3000 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ariz.;Ark.;Calif.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;Ga.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;Mont.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Utah;Vt.;Va.;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_909.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. |volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 527 |treatment_page=page 529 }}Stems 30–80(–100) cm, widely branched, sparsely hairy or glabrous. Leaves strongly bicolor (white and green, or gray-green and green), narrowly lanceolate, 4–10 × 0.5–1 cm, lobed; faces ± tomentose (abaxial) or glabrescent. Heads in paniculiform or racemiform arrays 1–8 × 2–5 cm. Involucres (campanulate) 3–4 × 2–3 mm. Florets: pistillate (5–)8–10; bisexual (6–)10–20; corollas ca. 1.5 mm. 2n = 18, 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer–late fall. |habitat=Mountain slopes, rocky soils |elevation=500–1000 m |distribution=Ariz.;Colo.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex.;Mexico. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. mexicana |authority=(Willdenow ex Sprengel) D. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. redolens |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) D. D. Keck |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Calif. Acad. species[[Artemisia ludoviciana]]
subspecies[[Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. redolens]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 527 |treatment_page=page 529 }}Stems 20–80 cm, mostly unbranched, glabrous. Leaves bicolor (white and green); blades lanceolate to ovate, 5–7 × 0.5–1 cm, irregularly pinnatifid; abaxial faces tomentose (abaxial) or glabrate (adaxial). Involucres campanulate, 2–3 × 2–3 mm. Heads in paniculiform or racemiform arrays 10–15 × 2–6 cm. Florets: pistillate ca. 10; bisexual 3–8; corollas 2 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Rocky loam soils |elevation=100–300 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia ludoviciana subsp. redolens |authority=(A. Gray) D. D. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia michauxiana |accepted_authority=Besser |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in W. J. Hooker, Fl. Bor.-Amer. |place=1: 324. 1833 |year=1833 }} |common_names=Lemon sagewort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia discolor |authority=Douglas ex Besser |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia vulgaris subsp. michauxiana |authority=(Besser) H. St. John |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia michauxiana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia michauxiana]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 522, 531 |treatment_page=page 530 }}Perennials, 30–100 cm, strongly aromatic (lemon-scented; rhizomatous). Stems relatively many, erect, green, simple, glabrous. Leaves cauline, green; blades broadly lanceolate to narrowly elliptic, 1.5–11 × 1–1.5 cm, 2-pinnately lobed, (ultimate lobes toothed), faces white-tomentose (abaxial) or glabrous (adaxial), yellow-gland-dotted. Heads (erect to nodding, peduncles 0 or to 10 mm) in paniculiform to spiciform arrays 8–15 × 1–1.5 cm. Involucres campanulate, 3(–4) × 2–5.5 mm. Phyllaries (yellow-green, rarely purplish) broadly ovate, glabrous or sparsely hairy, yellow-gland-dotted. Florets: pistillate 9–12; bisexual 15–35; corollas yellow, 1–1.5 mm, glandular. Cypselae (yellow to light brown) ellipsoid, ca. 0.5 mm, glabrous or glandular. 2n = 18, 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–early fall. |habitat=Talus slopes, alpine and subalpine drainages |elevation=1900–3700 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Yukon;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

Members of the Artemisia ludoviciana complex with deeply lobed leaves are sometimes confused with A. michauxiana, and there is evidence that plants hybridize in some locations. Artemisia michauxiana is distinguished by its glabrous, bright green to yellow-green foliage and lemony-sweet fragrance.

Fl. |publication_place=34: 244. 1916, }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. californica var. insularis |authority=(Rydberg) Munz |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. family[[Asteraceae]]

species[[Artemisia nesiotica]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 504, 520, 521, 524 |treatment_page=page 530 }}Subshrubs, 10–60 cm (rounded), aromatic. Stems relatively numerous, ascending or prostrate, gray, simple or branched (slender, wandlike, soft, bases woody and brittle), densely canescent. Leaves cauline, gray-green; blades linear-oblong, 3–5 × 1–2 cm, mostly 3-lobed (lobes 1–2 mm wide), faces gray-hairy. Heads (usually erect, sometimes nodding) in (leafy) paniculiform arrays 10–25 × 3–5(–7) cm. Involucres broadly campanulate, 2.5 × 4–4.5 mm. Phyllaries broadly ovate, densely hairy. Florets: pistillate 0; bisexual 20–50; corollas pale yellow, 1.2–1.5 mm, glandular. Cypselae (light brown) ellipsoid (ribbed), 0.5 mm, resinous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Rocky slopes, often fog-shrouded hillsides |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Artemisia nesiotica is known only from the Channel Islands of California. It differs from the closely related A. californica by its shorter stature, wider leaf lobes, and larger heads.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia nesiotica |authority=P. H. Artemisia |species=Artemisia nesiotica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia norvegica subsp. saxatilis |accepted_authority=(Besser) H. M. Hall & Clements |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Publ. Carnegie Inst. Wash. |place=326: 58. 1923 |year=1923 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Artemisia chamissoniana var. saxatilis |authority=Besser |rank=variety |publication_title=in W. J. Hooker, Fl. Bor.-Amer. |publication_place=1: 324. 1833 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia arctica |authority=Lessing |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia arctica subsp. beringensis |authority=(Hultén) Hultén |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia arctica subsp. comata |authority=(Rydberg) Hultén |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia arctica subsp. ehrendorferi |authority=Korobkov |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia arctica var. saxatilis |authority=(Besser) Y. R. Ling |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia comata |authority= |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia norvegica var. piceetorum |authority=S. L. Welsh & Goodrich |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia norvegica;Artemisia norvegica subsp. saxatilis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia norvegica]]
subspecies[[Artemisia norvegica subsp. saxatilis]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 530 }}Perennials, 25–40(–60) cm (not cespitose), mildly aromatic (roots often horizontal, woody). Stems 1–3, erect to ascending, green or reddish, simple, glabrous or sparsely tomentose. Leaves mostly basal (in rosettes, petiolate), bright green; blades (basal) broadly lanceolate, 5–8(–10) × 2–3(–4) cm, 1–3-pinnately lobed (apical lobes 1–7 × 1.5–3 mm; mid cauline sessile, pinnately lobed; on flowering stems, sessile, linear, entire), faces glabrous or hairy. Heads (nodding, proximalmost on peduncles to 50 mm) in racemiform arrays 10–17 × 1–2 cm. Involucres globose, (4–)5–8 × 4–10 mm. Phyllaries ovate-lanceolate to elliptic (margins dark brown to black), sparsely hairy to villous. Florets: pistillate 6–20; bisexual (30–)50–70; corollas yellow or red-tinged, 1.5–2.5(–3.5) mm, long-hairy. Cypselae ovoid-oblong (angular), ca. 2.5 mm, glabrous or villous. 2n = 18, 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Coastal, arctic, subalpine to alpine habitats, boreal forests, moist soils |elevation=0–3800 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Yukon;Alaska;Calif.;Colo.;Mont.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo.;e Asia (Russian Far East). |discussion=

Variation within Artemisia norvegica in North America is not well understood and, for that reason, this treatment represents a conservative taxonomy with only one subspecies for the flora area. Subspecies saxatilis differs from typical A. norvegica primarily by its larger heads. European plants have involucres less than 10 mm in diameter. Chromosome number may be used to justify separation of taxa either at the level of subspecies or species. If separated as distinct species, then A. arctica is the name for North American plants. The diploid A. arctica (2n = 18) and tetraploid A. comata (2n = 36) are treated as separate species by R. Elven et al. (pers. comm.).

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia norvegica subsp. saxatilis |authority=(Besser) H. M. Hall & Clements |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Artemisia arctica;Artemisia arctica subsp. beringensis;Artemisia arctica subsp. comata;Artemisia arctica subsp. ehrendorferi;Artemisia arctica var. saxatilis;Artemisia comata;Artemisia norvegica var. piceetorum |basionyms=Artemisia chamissoniana var. saxatilis |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Coastal, arctic, subalpine to alpine habitats, boreal forests, moist soils |elevation=0–3800 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Yukon;Alaska;Calif.;Colo.;Mont.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo.;e Asia (Russian Far East). |reference=None |publication title=Publ. Carnegie Inst. Wash. |publication year=1923 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_918.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae |genus=Artemisia |subgenus=Artemisia subg. Artemisia |species=Artemisia norvegica |subspecies=Artemisia norvegica subsp. saxatilis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia norvegica]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia nova |accepted_authority=A. Nelson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |place=27: 274. 1900 |year=1900 }} |common_names=Black sagebrush;black sage |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia arbuscula subsp. nova |authority=(A. Nelson) G. H. Ward |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia arbuscula var. nova |authority=(A. Nelson) Cronquist |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia tridentata subsp. nova |authority=(A. Nelson) H. M. Hall & Clements |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Seriphidium novum |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Tridentatae;Artemisia nova |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Tridentatae]]
species[[Artemisia nova]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 511, 514 |treatment_page=page 513 }}Shrubs, 10–30(–50) cm (trunks relatively short, widely and loosely branched), pungently aromatic; not root-sprouting. Stems brown, glabrescent (vegetative of approximately equal heights, giving plants a ‘hedged’ appearance; bark dark gray, exfoliating with age). Leaves persistent, usually bright green to dark green, sometimes gray-green; blades cuneate, 3-lobed (lobes to 1/3 blade lengths, 0.5–2 × 0.2–1 cm, rounded), faces sparsely hairy, gland-dotted. Heads in paniculiform arrays 4–10 × 0.5–3 cm (branches ± erect; peduncles slender). Involucres narrowly turbinate, 2–3 × 2 mm. Phyllaries (straw-colored or light green) ovate to elliptic (margins hyaline, shiny-resinous), sparsely hairy or glabrous. Florets 2–6; corollas 2–3 mm, glabrous (style branches scarcely exsert). Cypselae (ribbed) 0.8–1.5 mm, glabrous or resinous. 2n = 18, 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–late fall. |habitat=Shallow soils, desert valleys, exposed mountain slopes |elevation=1500–2300 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Utah;Wyo. |discussion=

Artemisia nova is the common low-growing dark-green (“black”) sagebrush of desert valleys or south-southwest-facing slopes. It is prized by sheep ranchers as forage in areas where little else is available for grazing. It is conspicuous by its low growth habit, dark green foliage, and, in late season, by its pale orange to light brown flowering branches that rise beyond the vegetative growth. Often confused in herbarium collections with A. arbuscula, A. nova is easily distinguished by the entire leaves of the flowering stems, pedunculate heads, narrowly turbinate involucres, and often straw-colored, glabrous or sparsely hairy phyllaries.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia nova |authority=A. Nelson |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms=Artemisia arbuscula subsp. nova;Artemisia arbuscula var. nova;Artemisia tridentata subsp. nova;Seriphidium novum |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid summer–late fall. |habitat=Shallow soils, desert valleys, exposed mountain slopes |elevation=1500–2300 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Utah;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Bull. Tridentatae |species=Artemisia nova }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Tridentatae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia packardiae |accepted_authority=J. W. Grimes & Ertter |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Brittonia |place=31: 454, fig. 1. 1979 |year=1979 }} |common_names=Succor Creek mugwort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia packardiae |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia packardiae]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 504, 522 |treatment_page=page 531 }}Perennials, 20–50(–60) cm, strongly aromatic (rhizomatous, fibrous-rooted). Stems 3–20, erect, light brown, simple or branched, glabrous. Leaves cauline, dark green; blades lanceolate, 1.5–5 × 1–2.5 cm, 2-pinnatifid (primary lobes 5–9, 0.4–1.5 cm; cauline smaller, pinnatifid to entire), faces tomentose (abaxial) or glabrous (adaxial). Heads (peduncles 0 or to 3 mm) in usually paniculiform, sometimes racemiform, arrays 5–20 × 1.5–4 cm. Involucres campanulate to hemispheric, 2.5–3.5 × 2–4.5 mm. Phyllaries broadly ovate, glandular (at least at bases). Florets: pistillate 3–8; bisexual, sometimes functionally staminate, (15–)20–35; corollas bright yellow, 1.3–2.2 mm, glandular. Cypselae (light brown) ellipsoid (± arcuate, ribs 4, prominent), ca. 1 mm, glandular. 2n = 18.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer. |habitat=Coarse taluses, alkaline soils, erosion gullies |elevation=1000–2400 m |distribution=Idaho;Nev.;Oreg. |discussion=

Artemisia packardiae is known only from southeastern Oregon, western Idaho, and northeastern Nevada. It is closely related to A. michauxiana and could be considered an ecologic variant.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia packardiae |authority=J. W. Artemisia |species=Artemisia packardiae }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia palmeri |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=11: 79. 1876 |year=1876 }} |common_names=Palmer sagewort |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisiastrum palmeri |authority=(A. Gray) Rydberg |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia palmeri |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia palmeri]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 531 |treatment_page= }}Subshrubs, 100–350 cm, mildly aromatic. Stems usually 1–15, erect, brown, simple (wandlike, brittle, bases woody), glabrous. Leaves cauline (petiolate), bicolor (gray-green and dark green); blades broadly lanceolate, 3.5–12(–15) × 0.2–10 cm, relatively deeply and coarsely pinnately lobed (lobes 3–7+), faces canescent (abaxial) or glabrous or sparsely hairy (adaxial). Heads (erect or nodding, peduncles relatively slender) in open, paniculiform arrays, 15–40 × 3–10 cm (widely branched). Involucres globose, 2.5–3.5 × 2–5 mm. Phyllaries (pale green to stramineous) broadly ovate, glabrous or sparsely hairy (receptacles paleate). Florets: pistillate 0; bisexual 8–30; corollas pale yellow, 1.5–2.2 mm, resinous-glandular (style branches exsert, truncate, erose). Cypselae (light brown, shiny) ellipsoid, 1–1.2 mm, (4-angled), glabrous or glandular. 2n = 18.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early–mid summer. |habitat=Ravines, coastal areas, sandy soils |elevation=100–300 m |distribution=Calif.;Mexico (Baja California). |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

Artemisia palmeri is known only from drainages near the coast, from northeast of San Diego to just south of Ensenada. Most of its habitat has been destroyed by urban development. It is of particular interest because of its paleate receptacles, an anomalous trait that confounds our understanding of its evolutionary relationship to other species of Artemisia.

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia papposa |accepted_authority=S. F. Blake & Cronquist |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Leafl. W. Bot. |place=6: 43, plate 1. 1950 |year=1950 }} |common_names=Owyhee sage |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia papposa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia papposa]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 487, 503, 521 |treatment_page=page 531 }}Shrubs, 5–15(–20) cm (not cespitose), aromatic. Stems relatively numerous, erect, gray, simple (annual flowering branches leafy), loosely sericeous. Leaves (semideciduous) cauline (sessile), gray-green; blades oblanceolate, 0.5–3 × 0.2–1.5 cm (bases attenuate), 3-lobed or irregularly palmatifid (lobes narrow, apices acute), sparsely sericeous-lanate. Heads (mostly erect, peduncles 0 or to 25 mm) in racemiform arrays (4–)8–12(–14) × (0.5–)1–2(–4) cm. Involucres globose, 3.5–5 × 4–5 mm. Phyllaries ovate, sparsely sericeous. Florets: pistillate 8; bisexual 20–35; corollas yellow (tubular with broad throats), ca. 2 mm, glandular. Cypselae (light brown) oblanceoloid (4–5-angled, broadest at truncate apices), 0.3–0.5 mm, glandular-pubescent (pappi coroniform, 0.3–0.6 mm, irregularly lacerate).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early spring–mid summer. |habitat=Rocky swales, dry meadows, alkaline mud flats |elevation=1400–2100 m |distribution=Idaho;Nev.;Oreg. |discussion=

The pappose cypselae make Artemisia papposa anomalous within Artemisia. Artemisia papposa has capitulescence characteristics that suggest a relationship to Sphaeromeria.

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia pattersonii |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. Gray et al., Syn. Fl. N. Amer. ed. |place=2, 1(2): 453. 1886 |year=1886 }} |common_names=Patterson sagewort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia monocephala |authority=(A. Gray) A. Heller |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia scopulorum var. monocephala |authority=A. Gray |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Absinthium;Artemisia pattersonii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Absinthium]]
species[[Artemisia pattersonii]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 519 |treatment_page=page 520 }}Perennials, 8–20 cm, mildly aromatic. Stems gray-brown, glabrate or finely pubescent. Leaves deciduous, gray-green; petiolate; blades (basal) broadly spatulate, 2–4 × 0.5 cm, pinnately lobed (lobes ca. 1.5 mm wide; cauline smaller, 1-pinnately lobed or entire), faces silky-hairy. Heads borne singly or (2–5, spreading to nodding, pedunculate) in paniculiform or racemiform arrays 1–5 × 0.5–1 cm. Involucres broadly hemispheric, 5–8 × 5–8(–10) mm. Phyllaries gray (margins dark brown to black), villous. Florets: pistillate 7–27; bisexual 32–100; corollas (yellow tinged with red), 2–3 mm (including exsert anthers), mostly glabrous (embedded in tangled receptacular hairs). Cypselae 1.5–2 mm, glabrous. 2n = 14.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Alpine meadows |elevation=3500–4000 m |distribution=Colo.;N.Mex.;Wyo. |discussion=

Artemisia pattersonii can be distinguished from the closely related A. scopulorum by its heads being borne singly and narrower phyllary margins.

Absinthium |species=Artemisia pattersonii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Absinthium]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia pedatifida |accepted_authority=Nuttall |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Trans. Amer. Philos. Soc., n. s. |place=7: 399. 1841 |year=1841 }} |common_names=Matted sagewort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Drancunculus;Artemisia pedatifida |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Drancunculus]]
species[[Artemisia pedatifida]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 505 |treatment_page=page 509 }}Perennials or subshrubs, 5–15 cm (cespitose), aromatic. Stems (5–20), gray-green, glabrescent. Leaves persistent, gray-green, mostly basal; proximal blades reduced, mostly less than 1 cm, lobed or entire; distal blades 1–2 × 0.5–0.8 cm, 1–2-ternately lobed, lobes 1–2 mm wide, apices acute, faces densely tomentose. Heads (mostly 6–15, 1 or 3–4 on lateral branches; mostly erect, sessile or pedunculate) in racemiform-paniculiform arrays, 5–8 × 0.5–0.8 cm. Involucres globose, 3–4 × 3–4 mm. Phyllaries (margins scarious, obscured) white-tomentose. Florets: pistillate 4–7; functionally staminate 5–9; corollas yellow, usually red-tinged, 2–3 mm, glabrous. Cypselae (brown) ellipsoid (angled), 0.8–1 mm, (sometimes with white ribs) glabrous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early spring–mid summer. |habitat=High plains, grasslands |elevation=1600–1800 m |distribution=Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Wyo. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia pedatifida |authority=Nuttall |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering early spring–mid summer. |habitat=High plains, grasslands |elevation=1600–1800 m |distribution=Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Trans. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia pontica |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=2: 847. 1753 |year=1753 }} |common_names=Roman wormwood;green-ginger;armoise de la mer Noire |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Artemisia;Artemisia pontica |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]
species[[Artemisia pontica]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 522, 532 |treatment_page=page 531 }}Perennials, 40–100 cm, somewhat aromatic; rhizomes creeping, woody. Stems relatively numerous, erect, brown, mostly simple (brittle, bases woody) canescent or glabrate. Leaves cauline, grayish green; sessile (proximalmost short-petiolate); blades triangular to ovate, 1–5 × 1–3 cm, 2–3-pinnatifid (lobes 0.5–1 mm wide, acute), faces pubescent (abaxial) or hairy to glabrate (adaxial). Heads (nodding) in paniculiform arrays 10–22 × 2–4 cm. Involucres spheric, 1.5–2(–3) mm. Phyllaries (subequal) linear, hairy. Florets: pistillate 10–12; bisexual 40–45; corollas pale yellow, 0.2–0.3 mm, sometimes gland-dotted (stigma lobes relatively short, not emerging from tubes, short-ciliate). Cypselae ellipsoid (angled), 0.1–0.2 mm, glabrous. 2n = 18.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer–fall. |habitat=Disturbed areas, valleys, shaded thickets |elevation=100–500 m |distribution=Man.;N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Conn.;Del.;Ill.;Ky.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Ohio;Pa.;R.I.;Vt.;Wis.;Eurasia. |introduced=true |discussion=

Artemisia pontica has finely dissected gray foliage and is widely planted as an ornamental. It escapes locally; it has not been reported as problematic. The only species with which it has been confused in North America is A. abrotanum, which has dark green (not gray) foliage.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia pontica |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering late summer–fall. |habitat=Disturbed areas, valleys, shaded thickets |elevation=100–500 m |distribution=Man.;N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Conn.;Del.;Ill.;Ky.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Ohio;Pa.;R.I.;Vt.;Wis.;Eurasia. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Sp. Artemisia |species=Artemisia pontica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Artemisia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia porteri |accepted_authority=Cronquist |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Madroño |place=11: 145. 1951 |year=1951 }} |common_names=Porter mugwort |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Drancunculus;Artemisia porteri |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Drancunculus]]
species[[Artemisia porteri]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 505 |treatment_page=page 509 }}Perennials or subshrubs, (7–)8–14 cm (cespitose), faintly aromatic. Stems 5–8, silver-gray, densely tomentose. Leaves persistent, silver-green, mostly basal; proximalmost blades 3–4 × 1–1.5 cm, 1-pinnately lobed, lobes mostly 2–3 mm wide; blades of flowering stems somewhat reduced, (1–)2–3(–5) × 0.15 cm, mostly entire; apices rounded, faces densely hairy. Heads borne singly or (clustered in 2s and 3s on lateral branches; peduncles 0 or to 5 mm) in paniculiform arrays, (2–)4–9 × 1–1.5(–2) cm. Involucres broadly campanulate, 4–5(–7) × 2–3 mm. Phyllaries (ovate, margins broadly scarious) densely tomentose. Florets: pistillate 8–10 (2–2.8 mm); functionally staminate 22–32; corollas pale yellow, 2.2–4.5 mm, glandular. Cypselae (light brown) ellipsoid, flattened (faintly nerved), 1.5–2 mm, sparsely hairy, glabrous or resinous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Barren clay and gravelly soils |elevation=1800–2000 m |distribution=Mont.;Wyo. |discussion=

Although Cronquist observed that Artemisia porteri may be an autopolyploid derivative of A. pedatifida, morphologic similarities to northerly cespitose taxa suggest a more complex origin.

Artemisia porteri is in the Center for Plant Conservation’s National Collection of Endangered Plants.

Drancunculus |species=Artemisia porteri }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Drancunculus]]

|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 505 |treatment_page=page 509 }}Perennials, 30–70(–100) cm, faintly aromatic. Stems usually 10+ (rising beyond basal leaves, decumbent), whitish gray, (ca. 5 mm diam., densely leafy) densely hairy. Leaves persistent, gray-green; blades broadly lanceolate, faces woolly-hairy; proximalmost blades 3–8 × 2–6 cm, 2–3-pinnatifid, lobes linear (to 2 mm wide); cauline somewhat reduced, 2–3 × 0.8–1.2 cm; apices acute, faces hairy. Heads (sessile, clustered in glomerules) in (densely leafy) paniculiform to spiciform arrays 10–20(–30) × 1–4 cm. Involucres globose, 3–4.5 × 3–4.5 mm. Phyllaries lanceolate, margins obscured by indument, hairs straight. Florets: pistillate 5–20; functionally staminate 12–25; corollas pale yellow (broadly tubular), ca. 2 mm, glabrous. Cypselae ellipsoid (faintly nerved), 1–1.5 mm, glabrous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Rocky or sandy soils of coastal beaches |elevation=0–200 m |distribution=Calif. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia pycnocephala |authority=(Lessing) de Candolle |rank=species |parent rank=subgenus |synonyms=Artemisia campestris subsp. pycnocephala |basionyms=Oligosporus pycnocephalus |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Rocky or sandy soils of coastal beaches |elevation=0–200 m |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=in A. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia pygmaea |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=21: 413. 1886 |year=1886 }} |common_names=Pygmy sage |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Seriphidium pygmaeum |authority=(A. Gray) W. A. Weber |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Tridentatae;Artemisia pygmaea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Tridentatae]]
species[[Artemisia pygmaea]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 504, 510 |treatment_page=page 514 }}Shrubs, 5–10 cm, slightly aromatic; not root-sprouting (caudices coarsely woody, branched). Stems pale to light brown (stiffly erect, densely clothed with appressed foliage), sparsely tomentose. Leaves persistent (sessile, rigid), bright green; blades oblong to ovate, 0.3–0.5 × 0.2–0.3 cm, pinnately lobed (nearly to midribs, 1/3+ widths of blades, lobes 3–7, divergent), faces glabrous or sparsely tomentose, resinous. Heads (sessile, erect) in paniculiform to racemiform arrays (1–)2–3 × 0.5–1 cm. Involucres narrowly turbinate, 2–3 × 3–4 mm. Phyllaries (green) narrowly lanceolate (midribs prominent), glabrous or sparsely tomentose. Florets 2–6; corollas 2.5–3 mm, glandular (style branches flat, erose, exsert). Cypselae (prismatic) 0.4–0.5 mm, glabrous, resinous. 2n = 18.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–fall. |habitat=Fine-textured soils of gypsum or shale |elevation=1500–1800 m |distribution=Ariz.;Colo.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Utah. |discussion=

Artemisia pygmaea is a distinctive, faintly aromatic shrublet, often mistaken for something other than a sagebrush. In early spring its stiff, bright green, deeply pinnatifid leaves are reminiscent of some prickly member of Polemoniaceae. After flowering, its heads and narrow panicles easily identify it as a member of Artemisia; it is unlike other members of the subgenus (which typically have 3-lobed leaves in fascicled lateral shoots). The molecular analysis by L. E. Watson et al. (2002) supported its phylogenetic alignment within subg. Tridentatae.

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia rigida |accepted_authority=(Nuttall) A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=19: 49. 1883 |year=1883 }} |common_names=Scabland sagebrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Artemisia trifida var. rigida |authority=Nuttall |rank=variety |publication_title=Trans. Amer. Philos. Soc., n. s. |publication_place=7: 398. 1841 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Seriphidium rigidum |authority=(Nuttall) W. A. Weber |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Tridentatae;Artemisia rigida |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Tridentatae]]
species[[Artemisia rigida]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 510 |treatment_page=page 515 }}Shrubs, 20–40 cm (branches widely spreading), mildly aromatic; root-sprouting (caudices stout). Stems gray (coarse, brittle), hairy (bark gray, exfoliating). Leaves deciduous, silver-gray (rigid); blades broadly spatulate, 1.5–4 × 0.5–0.7 cm (bases narrow), 3-lobed (lobes 1/2+ blade lengths, ca. 1 mm wide), faces densely hairy. Heads borne singly or (in glomerules) in (densely leafy) spiciform or paniculiform arrays 2–20 × 2 cm. Involucres narrowly campanulate, 4–5 × 2.5–3.5 mm. Phyllaries elliptic (acute to obtuse), densely canescent. Florets 4–8; corollas yellowish red to red, 2–2.8 mm (style branches oblong, truncate, exsert). Cypselae (4–5-ribbed) 1–1.5 mm, glabrous. 2n = 18, 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–early fall. |habitat=Dry rocky scablands, volcanic plains |elevation=1500–1800 m |distribution=Idaho;Mont.;Oreg.;Wash. |discussion=

Artemisia rigida is an important successional species following fires because the plants form new shoots from the underground caudices. This characteristic aligns the species with other ‘sprouters’ in the subgenus, namely A. cana, A. tripartita, and A. arbuscula.

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia rothrockii |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in W. H. Brewer et al., Bot. California |place=1: 618. 1876 |year=1876 }} |common_names=Rothrock or sticky sagebrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia tridentata subsp. rothrockii |authority=(A. Gray) H. M. Hall & Clements |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Seriphidium rothrockii |authority=(A. Gray) W. A. Weber |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Tridentatae;Artemisia rothrockii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Tridentatae]]
species[[Artemisia rothrockii]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 503, 510, 511 |treatment_page=page 515 }}Shrubs, 20–50 cm (sticky-resinous and dark green throughout), pungently aromatic; not root-sprouting (trunks relatively narrow). Stems white (becoming dark gray with age), canescent (bark exfoliating). Leaves persistent, light or dark gray-green; blades long-cuneate to lanceolate, (0.4–)1–1.5(–2) × 0.2–0.4 cm, 3-lobed (lobes to 1/3 blade lengths, rounded, margins sometimes entire, somewhat wavy), faces densely to sparsely canescent, gland-dotted, sticky-resinous. Heads (erect, sessile or pedunculate) in paniculiform arrays, 5–15 × 1–2(–3) cm. Involucres broadly ovoid, 3–5 × 4–6 mm. Phyllaries (usually gray-green) ovate, densely or sparsely canescent. Florets 12–20; corollas 2.5–3.5 mm. Cypselae 0.8–2 mm, (smooth), resinous. 2n = 36, 54, 72.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–all. |habitat=Clay soils of mountain meadows |elevation=2500–3100 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Artemisia rothrockii is known only from the central and southern Sierra Nevada and the White Mountains of California. In the Rocky Mountains, A. spiciformis has been confused with A. rothrockii. Distinctive chemistry and anatomical structure of the leaves support the distinctness of A. rothrockii (L. M. Shultz 1986b). Intermediate characteristics suggest a hybrid origin from races of A. cana and A. tridentata.

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia rupestris |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=2: 847. 1753 |year=1753 }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Absinthium viridifolium var. rupestre |authority=(Linnaeus) Besser |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Artemisia rupestris subsp. woodii |authority=Neilson |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae;Artemisia;Artemisia subg. Absinthium;Artemisia rupestris |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Anthemideae]]
genus[[Artemisia]]
subgenus[[Artemisia subg. Absinthium]]
species[[Artemisia rupestris]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 519 |treatment_page=page 520 }}Perennials, 5–15(–25) cm (cespitose), faintly aromatic. Stems brownish purple, glabrous. Leaves deciduous, bright green; blades (proximalmost petiolate) ovate, 1.5–5 × 1–2.5 cm, 2–3-pinnately lobed (cauline sessile, ternately or pinnately lobed, terminal lobes lance-linear, 1–6 × 0.5–1 mm), faces glabrous or sparsely hairy, glandular. Heads (5–9, pedunculate or sessile, spreading or drooping) in spiciform arrays 3–9 × 0.5–1 cm. Involucres globose, 4–5(–7) × 4–5(–7) mm. Phyllaries green (margins light green), ± hairy. Florets: pistillate 14–16 (glandular, style branches exsert, linear, spreading); bisexual 40–70; corollas 1.5–2 mm, glabrous or glandular (styles shorter than corollas). Cypselae ca. 1 mm (apices flat), glabrous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer–fall. |habitat=Steppes, alkaline meadows, stony slopes |elevation=0–1400 m |distribution=Yukon;Asia. |discussion=

The sole North American occurrence of Artemisia rupestris in southwestern Yukon is a remarkable disjunction from the Asiatic range of this species.

Absinthium |species=Artemisia rupestris }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Artemisia subg. Absinthium]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Artemisia scopulorum |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Acad. Nat. Sci. |volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 519 |treatment_page=page 520 }}Perennials, 10–25 cm (cespitose), mildly aromatic (caudices relatively slender). Stems gray-green, glabrate. Leaves persistent, gray-green; blades (basal) oblanceolate, 2–7 × 0.1 cm, 2-pinnately lobed (lobes linear or oblanceolate; cauline blades smaller, 1–2-pinnate or entire), faces silky-canescent. Heads (5–22) in spiciform arrays 5–9 × 1–1.5 cm. Involucres broadly globose or subglobose, 4 × 4–7 mm. Phyllaries green (margins black or dark brown), densely villous. Florets: pistillate 6–13; bisexual 15–30; corollas 1.5–2.5 mm, hairy (at least on lobes). Cypselae 0.8–1 mm, glabrous. 2n = 18.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late summer. |habitat=Alpine meadows, protected areas, bases of rocks |elevation=3100–4200 m |distribution=Colo.;Mont.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Utah;Wyo. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Artemisia scopulorum |authority=A.
